Gets the Y position of the current line's baseline, in layout coordinates.
Layout coordinates have the origin at the top left of the entire layout.
function.return: baseline of current line

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_char_extents
function.description:
Gets the extents of the current character, in layout coordinates.
Layout coordinates have the origin at the top left of the entire layout.
Only logical extents can sensibly be obtained for characters; ink extents make sense only down to the level of clusters.

parameter.name: logical_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with logical extents

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_cluster_extents
function.description:
Gets the extents of the current cluster, in layout coordinates.
Layout coordinates have the origin at the top left of the entire layout.

parameter.name: ink_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with ink extents

parameter.name: logical_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with logical extents

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_index
function.description:
Gets the current byte index.
Note that iterating forward by char moves in visual order, not logical order, so indexes may not be sequential. Also, the index may be equal to the length of the text in the layout, if on the %NULL run (see [method@Pango.LayoutIter.get_run]).
function.return: current byte index

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_layout
function.description:
Gets the layout associated with a `PangoLayoutIter`.
Since: 1.20
function.return: the layout associated with @iter

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_layout_extents
function.description: Obtains the extents of the `PangoLayout` being iterated over.

parameter.name: ink_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with ink extents

parameter.name: logical_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with logical extents

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_line
function.description:
Gets the current line.
Use the faster [method@Pango.LayoutIter.get_line_readonly] if you do not plan to modify the contents of the line (glyphs, glyph widths, etc.).
function.return: the current line

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_line_extents
function.description:
Obtains the extents of the current line.
Extents are in layout coordinates (origin is the top-left corner of the entire `PangoLayout`). Thus the extents returned by this function will be the same width/height but not at the same x/y as the extents returned from [method@Pango.LayoutLine.get_extents].

parameter.name: ink_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with ink extents

parameter.name: logical_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with logical extents

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_line_readonly
function.description:
Gets the current line for read-only access.
This is a faster alternative to [method@Pango.LayoutIter.get_line], but the user is not expected to modify the contents of the line (glyphs, glyph widths, etc.).
Since: 1.16
function.return: the current line, that should not be modified

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_line_yrange
function.description:
Divides the vertical space in the `PangoLayout` being iterated over between the lines in the layout, and returns the space belonging to the current line.
A line's range includes the line's logical extents. plus half of the spacing above and below the line, if [method@Pango.Layout.set_spacing] has been called to set layout spacing. The Y positions are in layout coordinates (origin at top left of the entire layout).
Note: Since 1.44, Pango uses line heights for placing lines, and there may be gaps between the ranges returned by this function.

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_run
function.description:
Gets the current run.
When iterating by run, at the end of each line, there's a position with a %NULL run, so this function can return %NULL. The %NULL run at the end of each line ensures that all lines have at least one run, even lines consisting of only a newline.
Use the faster [method@Pango.LayoutIter.get_run_readonly] if you do not plan to modify the contents of the run (glyphs, glyph widths, etc.).
function.return: the current run

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_run_baseline
function.description:
Gets the Y position of the current run's baseline, in layout coordinates.
Layout coordinates have the origin at the top left of the entire layout.
The run baseline can be different from the line baseline, for example due to superscript or subscript positioning.
Since: 1.50

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_run_extents
function.description:
Gets the extents of the current run in layout coordinates.
Layout coordinates have the origin at the top left of the entire layout.

parameter.name: ink_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with ink extents

parameter.name: logical_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to fill with logical extents

function.name: pango_layout_iter_get_run_readonly
function.description:
Gets the current run for read-only access.
When iterating by run, at the end of each line, there's a position with a %NULL run, so this function can return %NULL. The %NULL run at the end of each line ensures that all lines have at least one run, even lines consisting of only a newline.
This is a faster alternative to [method@Pango.LayoutIter.get_run], but the user is not expected to modify the contents of the run (glyphs, glyph widths, etc.).
Since: 1.16
function.return: the current run, that should not be modified

function.name: pango_layout_iter_next_char
function.description:
Moves @iter forward to the next character in visual order.
If @iter was already at the end of the layout, returns %FALSE.
function.return: whether motion was possible

function.name: pango_layout_iter_next_cluster
function.description:
Moves @iter forward to the next cluster in visual order.
If @iter was already at the end of the layout, returns %FALSE.
function.return: whether motion was possible

function.name: pango_layout_iter_next_line
function.description:
Moves @iter forward to the start of the next line.
If @iter is already on the last line, returns %FALSE.
function.return: whether motion was possible

function.name: pango_layout_iter_next_run
function.description:
Moves @iter forward to the next run in visual order.
If @iter was already at the end of the layout, returns %FALSE.
function.return: whether motion was possible

function.name: pango_layout_line_get_extents
function.description:
Computes the logical and ink extents of a layout line.
See [method@Pango.Font.get_glyph_extents] for details about the interpretation of the rectangles.

parameter.name: ink_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle used to store the extents of the glyph string as drawn

parameter.name: logical_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle used to store the logical extents of the glyph string

function.name: pango_layout_line_get_height
function.description:
Computes the height of the line, as the maximum of the heights of fonts used in this line.
Note that the actual baseline-to-baseline distance between lines of text is influenced by other factors, such as [method@Pango.Layout.set_spacing] and [method@Pango.Layout.set_line_spacing].
Since: 1.44

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the line height

function.name: pango_layout_line_get_length
function.description:
Returns the length of the line, in bytes.
Since: 1.50
function.return: the length of the line

function.name: pango_layout_line_get_pixel_extents
function.description:
Computes the logical and ink extents of @layout_line in device units.
This function just calls [method@Pango.LayoutLine.get_extents] followed by two [func@extents_to_pixels] calls, rounding @ink_rect and @logical_rect such that the rounded rectangles fully contain the unrounded one (that is, passes them as first argument to [func@extents_to_pixels]).

parameter.name: ink_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle used to store the extents of the glyph string as drawn

parameter.name: logical_rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle used to store the logical extents of the glyph string

function.name: pango_layout_line_get_resolved_direction
function.description:
Returns the resolved direction of the line.
Since: 1.50
function.return: the resolved direction of the line

function.name: pango_layout_line_get_start_index
function.description:
Returns the start index of the line, as byte index into the text of the layout.
Since: 1.50
function.return: the start index of the line

function.name: pango_layout_line_get_x_ranges
function.description:
Gets a list of visual ranges corresponding to a given logical range.
This list is not necessarily minimal - there may be consecutive ranges which are adjacent. The ranges will be sorted from left to right. The ranges are with respect to the left edge of the entire layout, not with respect to the line.

parameter.name: start_index
parameter.parameter_description: Start byte index of the logical range. If this value is less than the start index for the line, then the first range will extend all the way to the leading edge of the layout. Otherwise, it will start at the leading edge of the first character.

parameter.name: end_index
parameter.parameter_description: Ending byte index of the logical range. If this value is greater than the end index for the line, then the last range will extend all the way to the trailing edge of the layout. Otherwise, it will end at the trailing edge of the last character.

parameter.name: ranges
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a pointer to an array of ranges. The array will be of length `2*n_ranges`, with each range starting at `(*ranges)[2*n]` and of width `(*ranges)[2*n + 1] - (*ranges)[2*n]`. This array must be freed with g_free(). The coordinates are relative to the layout and are in Pango units.

parameter.name: n_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: The number of ranges stored in @ranges

function.name: pango_layout_line_index_to_x
function.description: Converts an index within a line to a X position.

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: byte offset of a grapheme within the layout

parameter.name: trailing
parameter.parameter_description: an integer indicating the edge of the grapheme to retrieve the position of. If > 0, the trailing edge of the grapheme, if 0, the leading of the grapheme

parameter.name: x_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the x_offset (in Pango units)

function.name: pango_layout_line_is_paragraph_start
function.description:
Returns whether this is the first line of the paragraph.
Since: 1.50
function.return: %TRUE if this is the first line

function.name: pango_layout_line_ref
function.description:
Increase the reference count of a `PangoLayoutLine` by one.
Since: 1.10
function.return: the line passed in.

function.name: pango_layout_line_unref
function.description:
Decrease the reference count of a `PangoLayoutLine` by one.
If the result is zero, the line and all associated memory will be freed.

function.name: pango_layout_line_x_to_index
function.description:
Converts from x offset to the byte index of the corresponding character within the text of the layout.
If @x_pos is outside the line, @index_ and @trailing will point to the very first or very last position in the line. This determination is based on the resolved direction of the paragraph; for example, if the resolved direction is right-to-left, then an X position to the right of the line (after it) results in 0 being stored in @index_ and @trailing. An X position to the left of the line results in @index_ pointing to the (logical) last grapheme in the line and @trailing being set to the number of characters in that grapheme. The reverse is true for a left-to-right line.

parameter.name: x_pos
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset (in Pango units) from the left edge of the line.

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: location to store calculated byte index for the grapheme in which the user clicked

parameter.name: trailing
parameter.parameter_description: location to store an integer indicating where in the grapheme the user clicked. It will either be zero, or the number of characters in the grapheme. 0 represents the leading edge of the grapheme.

function.return: %FALSE if @x_pos was outside the line, %TRUE if inside

function.name: pango_layout_move_cursor_visually
function.description:
Computes a new cursor position from an old position and a direction.
If @direction is positive, then the new position will cause the strong or weak cursor to be displayed one position to right of where it was with the old cursor position. If @direction is negative, it will be moved to the left.
In the presence of bidirectional text, the correspondence between logical and visual order will depend on the direction of the current run, and there may be jumps when the cursor is moved off of the end of a run.
Motion here is in cursor positions, not in characters, so a single call to this function may move the cursor over multiple characters when multiple characters combine to form a single grapheme.

parameter.name: strong
parameter.parameter_description: whether the moving cursor is the strong cursor or the weak cursor. The strong cursor is the cursor corresponding to text insertion in the base direction for the layout.

parameter.name: old_index
parameter.parameter_description: the byte index of the current cursor position

parameter.name: old_trailing
parameter.parameter_description: if 0, the cursor was at the leading edge of the grapheme indicated by @old_index, if > 0, the cursor was at the trailing edge.

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: direction to move cursor. A negative value indicates motion to the left

parameter.name: new_index
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the new cursor byte index. A value of -1 indicates that the cursor has been moved off the beginning of the layout. A value of %G_MAXINT indicates that the cursor has been moved off the end of the layout.

parameter.name: new_trailing
parameter.parameter_description: number of characters to move forward from the location returned for @new_index to get the position where the cursor should be displayed. This allows distinguishing the position at the beginning of one line from the position at the end of the preceding line. @new_index is always on the line where the cursor should be displayed.

function.name: pango_layout_new
function.description: Create a new `PangoLayout` object with attributes initialized to default values for a particular `PangoContext`.
function.return: the newly allocated `PangoLayout`

function.name: pango_layout_serialize
function.description:
Serializes the @layout for later deserialization via [func@Pango.Layout.deserialize].
There are no guarantees about the format of the output across different versions of Pango and [func@Pango.Layout.deserialize] will reject data that it cannot parse.
The intended use of this function is testing, benchmarking and debugging. The format is not meant as a permanent storage format.
Since: 1.50
function.return: a `GBytes` containing the serialized form of @layout

function.name: pango_layout_set_alignment
function.description:
Sets the alignment for the layout: how partial lines are positioned within the horizontal space available.
The default alignment is %PANGO_ALIGN_LEFT.

function.name: pango_layout_set_attributes
function.description:
Sets the text attributes for a layout object.
References @attrs, so the caller can unref its reference.

function.name: pango_layout_set_auto_dir
function.description:
Sets whether to calculate the base direction for the layout according to its contents.
When this flag is on (the default), then paragraphs in @layout that begin with strong right-to-left characters (Arabic and Hebrew principally), will have right-to-left layout, paragraphs with letters from other scripts will have left-to-right layout. Paragraphs with only neutral characters get their direction from the surrounding paragraphs.
When %FALSE, the choice between left-to-right and right-to-left layout is done according to the base direction of the layout's `PangoContext`. (See [method@Pango.Context.set_base_dir]).
When the auto-computed direction of a paragraph differs from the base direction of the context, the interpretation of %PANGO_ALIGN_LEFT and %PANGO_ALIGN_RIGHT are swapped.
Since: 1.4

parameter.name: auto_dir
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE, compute the bidirectional base direction from the layout's contents

function.name: pango_layout_set_ellipsize
function.description:
Sets the type of ellipsization being performed for @layout.
Depending on the ellipsization mode @ellipsize text is removed from the start, middle, or end of text so they fit within the width and height of layout set with [method@Pango.Layout.set_width] and [method@Pango.Layout.set_height].
If the layout contains characters such as newlines that force it to be layed out in multiple paragraphs, then whether each paragraph is ellipsized separately or the entire layout is ellipsized as a whole depends on the set height of the layout.
The default value is %PANGO_ELLIPSIZE_NONE.
See [method@Pango.Layout.set_height] for details.
Since: 1.6

function.name: pango_layout_set_font_description
function.description:
Sets the default font description for the layout.
If no font description is set on the layout, the font description from the layout's context is used.

parameter.name: desc
parameter.parameter_description: the new `PangoFontDescription` to unset the current font description

function.name: pango_layout_set_height
function.description:
Sets the height to which the `PangoLayout` should be ellipsized at.
There are two different behaviors, based on whether @height is positive or negative.
If @height is positive, it will be the maximum height of the layout. Only lines would be shown that would fit, and if there is any text omitted, an ellipsis added. At least one line is included in each paragraph regardless of how small the height value is. A value of zero will render exactly one line for the entire layout.
If @height is negative, it will be the (negative of) maximum number of lines per paragraph. That is, the total number of lines shown may well be more than this value if the layout contains multiple paragraphs of text. The default value of -1 means that the first line of each paragraph is ellipsized. This behavior may be changed in the future to act per layout instead of per paragraph. File a bug against pango at [https://gitlab.gnome.org/gnome/pango](https://gitlab.gnome.org/gnome/pango) if your code relies on this behavior.
Height setting only has effect if a positive width is set on @layout and ellipsization mode of @layout is not %PANGO_ELLIPSIZE_NONE. The behavior is undefined if a height other than -1 is set and ellipsization mode is set to %PANGO_ELLIPSIZE_NONE, and may change in the future.
Since: 1.20

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the desired height of the layout in Pango units if positive, or desired number of lines if negative.

function.name: pango_layout_set_indent
function.description:
Sets the width in Pango units to indent each paragraph.
A negative value of @indent will produce a hanging indentation. That is, the first line will have the full width, and subsequent lines will be indented by the absolute value of @indent.
The indent setting is ignored if layout alignment is set to %PANGO_ALIGN_CENTER.
The default value is 0.

parameter.name: indent
parameter.parameter_description: the amount by which to indent

function.name: pango_layout_set_justify
function.description:
Sets whether each complete line should be stretched to fill the entire width of the layout.
Stretching is typically done by adding whitespace, but for some scripts (such as Arabic), the justification may be done in more complex ways, like extending the characters.
Note that this setting is not implemented and so is ignored in Pango older than 1.18.
Note that tabs and justification conflict with each other: Justification will move content away from its tab-aligned positions.
The default value is %FALSE.
Also see [method@Pango.Layout.set_justify_last_line].

parameter.name: justify
parameter.parameter_description: whether the lines in the layout should be justified

function.name: pango_layout_set_justify_last_line
function.description:
Sets whether the last line should be stretched to fill the entire width of the layout.
This only has an effect if [method@Pango.Layout.set_justify] has been called as well.
The default value is %FALSE.
Since: 1.50

parameter.name: justify
parameter.parameter_description: whether the last line in the layout should be justified

function.name: pango_layout_set_line_spacing
function.description:
Sets a factor for line spacing.
Typical values are: 0, 1, 1.5, 2. The default values is 0.
If @factor is non-zero, lines are placed so that
baseline2 = baseline1 + factor * height2
where height2 is the line height of the second line (as determined by the font(s)). In this case, the spacing set with [method@Pango.Layout.set_spacing] is ignored.
If @factor is zero (the default), spacing is applied as before.
Note: for semantics that are closer to the CSS line-height property, see [func@Pango.attr_line_height_new].
Since: 1.44

function.name: pango_layout_set_markup
function.description:
Sets the layout text and attribute list from marked-up text.
See [Pango Markup](pango_markup.html)).
Replaces the current text and attribute list.
This is the same as [method@Pango.Layout.set_markup_with_accel], but the markup text isn't scanned for accelerators.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: length of marked-up text in bytes, or -1 if @markup is `NUL`-terminated

function.name: pango_layout_set_markup_with_accel
function.description:
Sets the layout text and attribute list from marked-up text.
See [Pango Markup](pango_markup.html)).
Replaces the current text and attribute list.
If @accel_marker is nonzero, the given character will mark the character following it as an accelerator. For example, @accel_marker might be an ampersand or underscore. All characters marked as an accelerator will receive a %PANGO_UNDERLINE_LOW attribute, and the first character so marked will be returned in @accel_char. Two @accel_marker characters following each other produce a single literal @accel_marker character.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: length of marked-up text in bytes, or -1 if @markup is `NUL`-terminated

parameter.name: accel_marker
parameter.parameter_description: marker for accelerators in the text

parameter.name: accel_char
parameter.parameter_description: return location for first located accelerator

function.name: pango_layout_set_single_paragraph_mode
function.description:
Sets the single paragraph mode of @layout.
If @setting is %TRUE, do not treat newlines and similar characters as paragraph separators; instead, keep all text in a single paragraph, and display a glyph for paragraph separator characters. Used when you want to allow editing of newlines on a single text line.
The default value is %FALSE.

function.name: pango_layout_set_spacing
function.description:
Sets the amount of spacing in Pango units between the lines of the layout.
When placing lines with spacing, Pango arranges things so that
line2.top = line1.bottom + spacing
The default value is 0.
Note: Since 1.44, Pango is using the line height (as determined by the font) for placing lines when the line spacing factor is set to a non-zero value with [method@Pango.Layout.set_line_spacing]. In that case, the @spacing set with this function is ignored.
Note: for semantics that are closer to the CSS line-height property, see [func@Pango.attr_line_height_new].

function.name: pango_layout_set_tabs
function.description:
Sets the tabs to use for @layout, overriding the default tabs.
`PangoLayout` will place content at the next tab position whenever it meets a Tab character (U+0009).
By default, tabs are every 8 spaces. If @tabs is %NULL, the default tabs are reinstated. @tabs is copied into the layout; you must free your copy of @tabs yourself.
Note that tabs and justification conflict with each other: Justification will move content away from its tab-aligned positions. The same is true for alignments other than %PANGO_ALIGN_LEFT.

function.name: pango_layout_set_text
function.description:
Sets the text of the layout.
This function validates @text and renders invalid UTF-8 with a placeholder glyph.
Note that if you have used [method@Pango.Layout.set_markup] or [method@Pango.Layout.set_markup_with_accel] on @layout before, you may want to call [method@Pango.Layout.set_attributes] to clear the attributes set on the layout from the markup as this function does not clear attributes.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: maximum length of @text, in bytes. -1 indicates that the string is nul-terminated and the length should be calculated. The text will also be truncated on encountering a nul-termination even when @length is positive.

function.name: pango_layout_set_width
function.description:
Sets the width to which the lines of the `PangoLayout` should wrap or get ellipsized.
The default value is -1: no width set.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the desired width in Pango units, or -1 to indicate that no wrapping or ellipsization should be performed.

function.name: pango_layout_set_wrap
function.description:
Sets the wrap mode.
The wrap mode only has effect if a width is set on the layout with [method@Pango.Layout.set_width]. To turn off wrapping, set the width to -1.
The default value is %PANGO_WRAP_WORD.

function.name: pango_layout_write_to_file
function.description:
A convenience method to serialize a layout to a file.
It is equivalent to calling [method@Pango.Layout.serialize] followed by [func@GLib.file_set_contents].
See those two functions for details on the arguments.
It is mostly intended for use inside a debugger to quickly dump a layout to a file for later inspection.
Since: 1.50

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the file to save it to

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for a potential error

function.return: %TRUE if saving was successful

function.name: pango_layout_xy_to_index
function.description:
Converts from X and Y position within a layout to the byte index to the character at that logical position.
If the Y position is not inside the layout, the closest position is chosen (the position will be clamped inside the layout). If the X position is not within the layout, then the start or the end of the line is chosen as described for [method@Pango.LayoutLine.x_to_index]. If either the X or Y positions were not inside the layout, then the function returns %FALSE; on an exact hit, it returns %TRUE.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset (in Pango units) from the left edge of the layout

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y offset (in Pango units) from the top edge of the layout

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: location to store calculated byte index

parameter.name: trailing
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a integer indicating where in the grapheme the user clicked. It will either be zero, or the number of characters in the grapheme. 0 represents the leading edge of the grapheme.

function.return: %TRUE if the coordinates were inside text, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: pango_log2vis_get_embedding_levels
function.description:
Return the bidirectional embedding levels of the input paragraph.
The bidirectional embedding levels are defined by the [Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm](http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr9/).
If the input base direction is a weak direction, the direction of the characters in the text will determine the final resolved direction.
Since: 1.4

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes (not characters) to process, or -1 if @text is nul-terminated and the length should be calculated.

parameter.name: pbase_dir
parameter.parameter_description: input base direction, and output resolved direction.

function.return: a newly allocated array of embedding levels, one item per character (not byte), that should be freed using [func@GLib.free].

function.name: pango_lookup_aliases
function.description:
Look up all user defined aliases for the alias @fontname.
The resulting font family names will be stored in @families, and the number of families in @n_families.
Deprecated: 1.32: This function is not thread-safe.

parameter.name: families
parameter.parameter_description: will be set to an array of font family names. This array is owned by Pango and should not be freed

parameter.name: n_families
parameter.parameter_description: will be set to the length of the @families array

function.name: pango_map_get_engine
function.description:
Do not use. Does not do anything.
Deprecated: 1.38
function.return: %NULL.

function.name: pango_map_get_engines
function.description:
Do not use. Does not do anything.
Since: 1.4 Deprecated: 1.38

parameter.name: exact_engines
parameter.parameter_description: location to store list of engines that exactly handle this script.

parameter.name: fallback_engines
parameter.parameter_description: location to store list of engines that approximately handle this script.

function.name: pango_markup_parser_finish
function.description:
Finishes parsing markup.
After feeding a Pango markup parser some data with [method@GLib.MarkupParseContext.parse], use this function to get the list of attributes and text out of the markup. This function will not free @context, use [method@GLib.MarkupParseContext.free] to do so.
Since: 1.31.0

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: A valid parse context that was returned from [func@markup_parser_new]

parameter.name: attr_list
parameter.parameter_description: address of return location for a `PangoAttrList`

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: address of return location for text with tags stripped

parameter.name: accel_char
parameter.parameter_description: address of return location for accelerator char

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: address of return location for errors

function.return: %FALSE if @error is set, otherwise %TRUE

function.name: pango_markup_parser_new
function.description:
Incrementally parses marked-up text to create a plain-text string and an attribute list.

* Find the `PangoOTTag` script and language tags associated with @script and @language using [func@PangoOT.tag_from_script] and [func@PangoOT.tag_from_language],
* For each of table types %PANGO_OT_TABLE_GSUB and %PANGO_OT_TABLE_GPOS, find the script index of the script tag found and the language system index of the language tag found in that script system, using [method@PangoOT.Info.find_script] and [method@PangoOT.Info.find_language],

For some scripts, no sample language will be returned because there is no language that is sufficiently representative. The best example of this is %PANGO_SCRIPT_HAN, where various different variants of written Chinese, Japanese, and Korean all use significantly different sets of Han characters and forms of shared characters. No sample language can be provided for many historical scripts as well.
As of 1.18, this function checks the environment variables `PANGO_LANGUAGE` and `LANGUAGE` (checked in that order) first. If one of them is set, it is parsed as a list of language tags separated by colons or other separators. This function will return the first language in the parsed list that Pango believes may use @script for writing. This last predicate is tested using [method@Pango.Language.includes_script]. For example, a `PANGO_LANGUAGE` enviroment variable set to "en:fa" makes Pango choose fonts suitable for Persian (fa) instead of Arabic (ar) when a segment of Arabic text is found in an otherwise non-Arabic text. function.name: pango_win32_font_description_from_logfont
function.description:
Creates a `PangoFontDescription` that matches the specified LOGFONTA.
The face name, italicness and weight fields in the LOGFONTA are used to set up the resulting `PangoFontDescription`. If the face name in the LOGFONTA contains non-ASCII characters the font is temporarily loaded (using CreateFontIndirect()) and an ASCII (usually English) name for it is looked up from the font name tables in the font data. If that doesn't work, the face name is converted from the system codepage to UTF-8 and that is used.

function.return: the newly allocated `PangoFontDescription`, which should be freed using [method@Pango.FontDescription.free]

The face name, italicness and weight fields in the LOGFONTW are used to set up the resulting `PangoFontDescription`. If the face name in the LOGFONTW contains non-ASCII characters the font is temporarily loaded (using CreateFontIndirect()) and an ASCII (usually English) name for it is looked up from the font name tables in the font data.
